author: The Canadian Press
title: Canadians Paralympians strike gold twice, with one bronze on Day 8
text:
Canadians Paralympians strike gold twice, with one bronze on Day 8
PARIS â€“ Canada earned three medals, with two golds courtesy of two of its biggest names at the Paralympic Games on Day 8.
Wheelchair racer Brent Lakatos earned gold in the menâ€™s T53 800 metres on the track on Thursday, while Aurelie Rivard picked up gold in the womenâ€™s S10 400-metre freestyle in the pool. Swimmer Tess Routliffe added bronze in the womenâ€™s SB7 100-metre breaststroke.
For the 44-year-old Lakatos, it was career medal No. 13 and his first Paralympic gold since the 2016 Games when he won the 100. The Dorval, Que., native won four silvers at the Tokyo Paralympics in 2021.
â€œItâ€™s a really great feeling,â€ said Lakatos, who is competing in his fifth Paralympics. â€œThis has taken a lot of planning. The Canadian support staff have been great.
â€œWe had a great strategy, taking control of the race. We executed the plan and it worked out really well.â€
Lakatos now has two medals in Paris, having also taken silver in the 400. But it was a tough road.
â€œMy training has been modified due to a broken rib,â€ he said. â€œBut I was able to get back for here and Iâ€™m obviously in great shape. I had a stress fracture. I was in really great shape then something started hurting at the very end of May.
â€œLuckily I had just enough time to get back, though I missed the whole competition season. Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™ve got no seasonâ€™s bests.â€
Meanwhile, for the 28-year-old Rivard, it was also career medal No. 13 and her third in Paris. Rivard also earned bronze in the 50 freestlye and silver in the 100 freestyle.
The St-Jean-sur-Richelieu, Que., native became the first Canadian swimmer to win a gold medal in the same event in three consecutive Paralympic Games since Stephanie Dixon won the S9 100 backstroke in 2000, 2004, and 2008.
While calling it a surreal moment, Rivard referenced back to her silver in the 100 freestyle, an event she had won gold in at the previous two Paralympics. She was disappointed and even said she thought of going home after it, adding she had not swam that slow in 10 years.
â€œI had to find the confidence to show up tonight and deliver,â€ Rivard said. â€œIt took a lot and I am really proud. I am happy I was able to overcome my fears.â€
For Routliffe, it was a long time coming after finishing fourth eight years ago at the 2016 Rio Paralympics.
The 25-year-old was unable to compete at the Tokyo Games in 2021 due to a back injury as well.
â€œIt was a good race. I get in the water and I just want to race the person next to me,â€ Routliffe said. â€œThatâ€™s exactly what I did. I put my heart into that race and I am happy to be on the podium again.
â€œGetting on that podium is huge. Weâ€™ve been working on that race a lot. Those girls are quick. Just got to get out and race them.â€
Itâ€™s the second medal of these Games for Routliffe, having also earned silver in the SM7 200-metre individual medley.
In womenâ€™s sitting volleyball, Canada will play Brazil for bronze on Saturday. The Canadians fell 3-0 to China on Thursday in the semifinals.
Canadaâ€™s menâ€™s wheelchair basketball squad will play Germany for bronze on Saturday.
The Canadians fell 80-43 to the United States in the semifinals on Thursday. Patrick Anderson paced Canada with 16 points.
Itâ€™s the first time Canada will play for a medal since winning gold at the 2012 London Games.
Canada fell 6-1 to Thailand in the bronze-medal game in mixed pairs BC4 boccia action.
In judo action, Priscilla Gagne of Sarnia, Ont., lost her bronze-medal match against Argentinaâ€™s Paula Karina Gomez.
This report by The Canadian Press was first published Sept. 5, 2024.

author: Kamya Pandey
title: Indiaâ€™s Broadband Subscriptions Drop to 944.4M in September, Marking 2024â€™s First Decline
text:
Broadband connections in India have dropped by 0.51% to 944.4 million in September 2024, from 949.21 million in August . This is the first time in 2024 that India has seen a decline in broadband connections this year. This loss of connections is coming from a decline in India’s wireless connection base which went from 906.37 million to 900.77 million. Further, within the wireless connections, mobile connections (phones and dongles) declined by 0.63% going from 905.46 million to 899.79 million in September.\xa0

This decline in subscribers comes after the three major private telcos— Reliance Jio, Bharti Airtel and Vodafone Idea (Vi)— increased the prices of their internet plans in July this year. Given that the tariff hike was directed towards mobile connections , this decline in subscribers could be motivated by the higher prices.\xa0

 
On the other hand, in the fixed wireless segment (like Wi-Fi), connections have increased by 9.01% going from 0.91 million in August to 0.99 million in September. Similarly, wired connections in India also increased by 1.83% going from 42.84 million in August to 43.63 million in September.\xa0

 Other observations from the data: 
 Jio sees further decline in subscriber base: 
Jio’s broadband connections have been falling since July. In June, the company had 488.94 million connections, which have since fallen to 477.94 million as of September. Specifically between August and September, the company lost 7.35 million connections. The decline in connections across the past few months is coming from the wireless segment, which, between August and September, fell from 471.75 million to 463.78 million.\xa0

In its most recent earnings call , Jio acknowledged that on a quarterly basis, it has lost about 11 million subscribers as of September 30. The company said that this subscriber decline was nothing unusual with its CFO V Srikanth adding that this was lower than the subscriber decline the company saw in its past tariff hike.

 Airtel and Vi see subscriber increases: 
While all three companies increased prices, Airtel and Vi did not lose broadband connections in September. On the contrary, Airtel’s connections went from 284.04 million in August to 284.55 million in September, and Vi’s connection base grew from 125.92 million to 126.36 million.\xa0

Between the two companies, Vi was the only one who experienced a hit because of the tariff hike in the past couple of months. In June, the company used to have 127.82 million connections, however, its connection base dropped to 125.92 by August, only to recover by 0.44 million in September. Just like Jio, Vi has also previously addressed the impact of tariff hikes, stating that its customers have temporarily shifted to BSNL and will return back. “Customers who are used to a good coverage, and experience of 4G, probably the current offering of BSNL may not be to that extent,” Vi\xa0 CEO Akshay Moondra said in August .

 BSNL benefits from private telcos’ tariff hike: 
As Jio loses its subscriber base, BSNL has been steadily seeing an improvement in wireless connections. Between August and September, BSNL’s total broadband connection base grew by 1.53 million. The growth in connections is coming from the wireless segment which increased from 32 million to 33.5 million in September.\xa0

 Airtel maintains a prominent position in the M2M market: 
Airtel’s machine-to-machine (M2M) connections stood at 28.44 million in September which is a slight increase of 0.3 million from August. The company maintains a market share of 52.06% followed by Vi, Reliance Jio Infocom Limited and BSNL with a market share of 27.12%, 15.29%, and 5.54% respectively. Total M2M connections in India stood at 54.64 million in September 2024.\xa0

 
 Source: TRAI Data

text:

SegÃºn Tesoro de Estados Unidos publicado el jueves, el jefe de la AsociaciÃ³n de Cambiadores de Divisas en SanÃ¡ (capital yemenÃ­), asÃ­ como tres casas de cambio en Yemen y TurquÃ­a, son objeto de nuevas sanciones de Washington.
Los castigados, tal como afirma el Tesoro de EE.UU., son responsables de â€œfacilitar el flujo de asistencia financieraâ€ al Gobierno de SalvaciÃ³n Nacional de Yemen y al movimiento popular de AnsarolÃ¡.
Las medidas punitivas congelan cualquier activo estadounidense que pertenezca a las aludidas entidades y, en general, prohÃ­ben a los estadounidenses hacer negocios con estas.
Yemen tiene pulso de la economÃ­a global El subsecretario del Tesoro para Terrorismo e Inteligencia Financiera, Brian E. Nelson, ha acusado a las fuerzas militares de Yemen de realizar ataques peligrosos contra el transporte marÃ­timo internacional y desestabilizar la regiÃ³n.

Las fuerzas yemenÃ­es han advertido que impedirÃ¡n el paso de todos los buques en el mar con destino a puertos en los territorios ocupados por Israel.
En reacciÃ³n, EE.UU. implementÃ³ la formaciÃ³n de una alianza , denominada operaciÃ³n GuardiÃ¡n de la Prosperidad y que iba a ser la mayor coaliciÃ³n naval internacional, para contrarrestar en el mar Rojo los ataques lanzados desde Yemen. La iniciativa estadounidense, sin embargo, naciÃ³ moribunda, pues casi ningÃºn paÃ­s regional se adhiriÃ³ al grupo, entre otras causas.
Desde Yemen, ademÃ¡s de restar importancia a la coaliciÃ³n militar liderada por Estados Unidos, aseguraron que cualquier paÃ­s que se anexe al grupo, entrarÃ­a en la mira de sus potentes ataques.
Yemen: Cualquier paÃ­s que se una a coaliciÃ³n estarÃ¡ en nuestra mira
EEUU y amigos contra hÃ©rcules, Yemen | PoliMedios | HISPANTV EE.UU. ha formado una coaliciÃ³n para contrarrestar en el mar Rojo los ataques lanzados desde Yemen contra los barcos con destino a Israel en solidaridad con Gaza.
Aun con todo, las fuerzas yemenÃ­es han prometido continuar las operaciones en apoyo al pueblo palestino, hasta que Israel frene completamente la brutal campaÃ±a de agresiones contra la sitiada Franja de Gaza, que desde el 7 de octubre ha dejado mÃ¡s de 21 000 muertos, la mayorÃ­a mujeres y niÃ±os.

author: Frank Daly
title: Are taxis safe in Zurich?
text:
Are taxis safe in Zurich?
Yes, taxis in Zurich are considered safe for travelers. They are known to be clean, reliable, and operated by licensed drivers. However, itâ€™s always advisable to take normal precautions when using taxis in any city.
Is it easy to get a taxi in Zurich?
Yes, it is generally easy to find a taxi in Zurich, even during busy periods like weekend nights. There are 1550 licensed taxis in the city, and taxi stands can be found at key locations such as Zurichâ€™s Main Railway Station, BÃ¼rkliplatz, and Lake Zurich.
How do I pay a taxi in Zurich?
Taxis in Zurich usually accept payment by credit card, but itâ€™s a good idea to ask the driver before getting in. If you donâ€™t speak German, be prepared to show the driver your address written down. Tipping taxi drivers is not common in Switzerland, but rounding up the bill if youâ€™re satisfied with the service is appreciated.
How much is a taxi from Zurich airport to the city?
The cost of a taxi from Zurich Airport to the city center is around CHF 50-70. In most taxis, there is a basic fare of CHF 6, and an additional CHF 3.80 per kilometer. Itâ€™s important to note that if you have a lot of luggage, there may be an additional surcharge.
Do taxis in Zurich take credit cards?
Yes, taxis in Zurich generally accept credit cards as a form of payment. However, itâ€™s always a good idea to check with the driver before getting in to make sure they accept credit cards. Other accepted payment methods include cash, Maestro cards, and any other available payment options.
Do you tip taxi drivers in Zurich?
Tipping taxi drivers in Switzerland is not common, but rounding up the bill or leaving a small tip is appreciated if you were satisfied with the service. Itâ€™s especially common to round up the amount to the nearest significant amount in Swiss francs.
Are there Ubers in Zurich?
Yes, Uber operates in Zurich, making it a convenient alternative to traditional taxis. You can book an Uber through the Uber app, and the fare will vary depending on the distance and demand.
How do I call a taxi in Zurich?
To call a taxi in Zurich, you can simply dial 044 777 77 77. This number allows you to order a taxi service or you can also use the website of the taxi company for a convenient fixed fare.
What is the best way of transportation in Zurich?
The best way to get around Zurich is on foot or by cycling. The city is known for its walkability and there are also bike-friendly routes. Additionally, Zurich has an efficient tram system that can be used for longer distances. From Zurich Airport, you can take a train into the city, which is only around 6 miles away and takes approximately 20 minutes.
Do I need cash in Zurich?
The most commonly accepted payment options in Zurich are cash, credit cards, and debit cards. Credit cards and debit cards are accepted almost everywhere, and the most common ones are Visa, Mastercard, American Express, and Maestro.
Are taxi expensive in Zurich?
Generally speaking, taxis in Switzerland, including Zurich, tend to be relatively expensive compared to other countries. For example, a 5-kilometer ride in a major city in Switzerland, such as Zurich, can cost around CHF 25-30.
Do taxis take credit cards in Switzerland?
Yes, taxis in Switzerland, including Zurich, typically accept credit cards as a form of payment. However, itâ€™s always a good idea to check with the driver before getting in to confirm that they accept credit cards. Other accepted payment methods include cash, Maestro cards, and other available payment options.
Is Zurich a walkable city?
Yes, Zurich is a highly walkable city. You can easily explore the city on foot and enjoy its beautiful spots and attractions. In fact, Zurich encourages walking as a means of transportation and provides pedestrian-friendly paths throughout the city.
What taxi app does Switzerland use?
YOURTAXI is a popular taxi app in Zurich and throughout Switzerland. It provides a convenient way to book a taxi by specifying your current location and desired destination. The app also offers various options for different types of taxis.
Is public transport free in Zurich for tourists?
No, public transport in Zurich is not free for tourists. However, you can purchase a Zurich Card, which offers free travel on public transport in the city and surrounding areas. The Zurich Card also provides free or discounted admission to museums and other attractions.
Can I get a taxi from Zurich Airport?
Yes, taxis are readily available at Zurich Airport. You can find taxi ranks in front of Arrivals 1 and 2. Simply queue at the taxi ranks and wait for the next available taxi. Taxis can be recognized by their taxi sign on the roof. Itâ€™s important to note that fares from the airport to the city center typically range from CHF 50-70.
How do you ask for the bill in Switzerland?
When you are ready to ask for the bill in Switzerland, you can simply flag down your waiter and say â€œlâ€™addition sâ€™il vous plaÃ®t,â€ which means â€œthe bill, please.â€ In most Swiss restaurants, the waitstaff will not automatically bring the bill at the end of the meal, so itâ€™s common to request it when you are ready to pay.
Is it rude not to tip in Switzerland?
While tipping is not as common in Switzerland as it is in some other countries, itâ€™s not considered rude to not tip. However, rounding up the bill or leaving a small tip as a sign of appreciation for good service is generally appreciated. Some restaurants may include a service charge in the bill, so itâ€™s always a good idea to check before tipping.
Is it safe to take a taxi at night in Zurich?
Yes, it is generally safe to take a taxi at night in Zurich. The city has a low crime rate, and licensed taxis are considered safe for travelers. However, itâ€™s always a good idea to exercise normal caution and be aware of your surroundings when using taxis or any form of transportation in a new city.
How can I book a taxi in Zurich?
To book a taxi in Zurich, you can use the phone number 044 777 77 77 or visit the taxi companyâ€™s website. This will allow you to order a taxi service and benefit from the convenience of a fixed fare. Additionally, you can also find taxis at designated taxi stands throughout the city.
Do taxis in Zurich speak English?
Many taxi drivers in Zurich can speak English, especially

author: @WSMV
title: TN AG calls for action against sellers of counterfeit, contaminated weight-loss drugs
text:
TN AG calls for action against sellers of counterfeit, contaminated weight-loss drugs
â€œMillions of Americans rely on GLP-1 drugs to improve their health, but bad actors are peddling dangerous fakes.â€
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WSMV) - Tennessee Attorney General Jonathan Skrmetti, among other attorneys general, is calling for the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to take action against the sale of counterfeit and unsafe forms of the weight loss and diabetes drugs Ozempic, Wegovy, Mounjaro, and Zepbound (GLP-1 drugs).
â€œMillions of Americans rely on GLP-1 drugs to improve their health, but bad actors are peddling dangerous fakes,â€ said AG Skrmetti. â€œThese counterfeit or copycat drugs can be contaminated through shady supply chains running from China, Turkey, and other overseas suppliers, or they can contain entirely different drugs manufactured and packaged to look like GLP-1 drugs. We are asking the FDA to lead efforts to safeguard our American supply chain and to work with other federal and state agencies to stop bad actors from producing counterfeit drugs.â€
He said that the sky-high demand for GLP-1 drugs alongside high price tags and tight supplies is creating opportunities for bad actors to take advantage of consumers. Skrmetti said that thereâ€™s been an increase of the manufacturing and selling of counterfeit, untested products.
â€œAnd counterfeit versions pose not only a risk to public health but also to our national security. There are reports that counterfeit GLP-1 drugs from India, Turkey, China, and other foreign sources have infiltrated the U.S. supply chain,â€ he said.
